content:
• Wednesday, August 19, 2015
  • ANFI

    Amira hiring new accounting firm, external investigators; shares -14%

    • Amira Nature Foods (NYSE:ANFI) has fired accounting firm Deloitt Haskins & Sells, and hired ASA & Associates to be its new independent auditor. ASA will "commence work immediately to audit the Company's financial results for the fiscal year ended March 31, 2015."
    • Amira's audit committee has also "elected to appoint an independent external investigative firm." In a 6-K filing, the company states Deloitte Haskins "requested the Audit Committee retain independent external forensic investigators to conduct an investigation into (i) the issues raised in a short seller report dated July 30, 2015 and (ii) other transactions identified by Deloitte Haskins & Sells LLP in connection with its incomplete audit of the Company’s financial statements for the year ended March 31, 2015."
    • The "short seller report" in question was published by SA author Prescience Point, and raised a number of accounting, balance sheet, and cash flow questions. Last week, Amira announced it's suing Prescience Point and others for allegedly "disseminating material false, misleading, and defamatory information."
    • Shares have plunged to $4.00 after hours, making new 52-week lows in the process.
     
     
     
     
    | 6:32 PM | 8 Comments
  • YOKU

    Youku Tudou up 3.7% after Q2 beat on top, bottom lines

    • China's net-TV leader Youku Tudou (NYSE:YOKU) is up 3.7% after hours in U.S. trading, as the company posted "accelerated and increasingly diversified" top-line growth and posted a better-than-expected loss for Q2.
    • Net loss widened significantly, to 220.7M yuan ($35.6M) on a non-GAAP basis, compared with a loss of 76.9M yuan ($12.4M) in the year-ago period. The company had guided high of expectations for revenue and delivered with 1.61B yuan.
    • Content costs were up slightly again, to a non-GAAP 649.8M yuan ($104.8M), representing 43% of net revenues compared to a year-ago 42%. Gross profit of 253.8M yuan ($41M) was up 14%.
    • "With nearly half of advertising revenues coming from mobile, we have achieved broad adoption of mobile advertising by domestic and international advertisers alike," said CEO Victor Koo.
    • The company's guiding to Q3 revenues between RMB1.69B and RMB1.78B, and advertising net revenues of RMB1.34B-RMB1.4B.
    • Shares had closed 5% lower during U.S. market hours; they're down 15.1% over the past month.
    • Conference call to come at 9 p.m. ET.
     
     
     
     
    | 6:28 PM
  • LF

    LeapFrog gets bullish coverage from Oppenheimer; shares +2.9%

    • Oppenheimer has launched coverage on LeapFrog (NYSE:LF) with an Outperform rating and $3 target.
    • Shares have risen to $0.98 after hours. They remain down 79% YTD, as liquidity/solvency fears continue running high following multiple earnings disappointments. LeapFrog ended March with $88.2M in cash, down from $199.2M a year earlier and above a current market cap of $69M.
     
     
     
     
    | 6:06 PM | 2 Comments
  • SMTC

    Semtech down 3.5% due to soft FQ3 guidance

    • While Semtech (NASDAQ:SMTC) beat FQ2 revenue estimates and posted in-line EPS, it's guiding for FQ3 revenue of $110M-$120M and EPS of $0.21-$0.27, below a consensus of $129.5M and $0.29.
    • Enterprise-related sales were strong in FQ2, but demand from Semtech's other three end-markets fell, and the company reiterates sales to Korean smartphone OEMs are weak. Samsung is known to be a major client.
    • Given top-line pressures, gross margin held up fairly well, falling just 40 bps Q/Q and Y/Y to 60.4%. GAAP operating costs/expenses rose 10% Y/Y to $72.5M - job cuts were announced in mid-July.
    • Shares have fallen to $15.50 after hours. Various analog/mixed-signal peers have also issued soft Q3 guidance in recent weeks. However, with the midpoint of Semtech's revenue guidance range implying a 23% Y/Y sales drop, its outlook also implies share loss.
    • FQ2 results, PR
     
     
     
     
    | 5:51 PM

  • After Hours Gainers / Losers

    • Top gainers, as of 5.25 p.m.: ACI +12.0%. KEYS +9.0%. NTAP +5.5%. SSW +3.3%. BBRG +2.5%.
    • Top losers, as of 5.25p.m.: ANFI -17.0%. MOMO -11.5%. JMEI -4.4%. VEEV -3.5%. LB -2.0%.
     
     
     
     
    | 5:37 PM
  • LB

    Guidance from L Brands arrives below estimates

    • L Brands (NYSE:LB) raises full-year EPS guidance to $3.58-$3.73 vs. $3.50-$3.70 prior and $3.73 consensus.
    • Q3 EPS guidance is set at $0.40-$0.45 vs. $0.47 consensus.
    • General expenses including store operating costs at L Brands have been growing slightly faster than some estimates.
    • Previously: L Brands EPS in-line, misses on revenue (Aug. 19)
    • LB -1.08% in after-hours trading.
     
     
     
     
    | 5:32 PM | 1 Comment
  • JMEI

    Jumei down 4.4% in spite of Q2 beat; guidance in-line

    • Jumei (NYSE:JMEI) is guiding for Q3 revenue of $287M-$291.8M, up 82%-85% Y/Y and in-line with a $288M consensus.
    • Net GMV (covers both direct and marketplace sales) rose 30% Y/Y in Q2 to $376.2M, active customers rose 28% to 6.4M, and orders 58.2% to 17.4M. "Customer purchase frequency" is said to be up 34% since Q3, thanks partly to Jumei's expansion into the baby/maternity and health/wellness product categories. Jumei Global (offers international products) was a key growth driver.
    • Possibly putting investors on edge: Gross margin remained under pressure in spite of huge top-line growth, falling to 30% from Q1's 31.4% and Q2 2014's 46.3%. Jumei blames a mix shift from beauty product marketplace sales to merchandise sales. Operating expenses rose 55.4% Y/Y to $78.3M (compares with 99.5% revenue growth).
    • Shares have fallen to $16.00 after hours.
    • Q2 results, PR
     
     
     
     
    | 5:31 PM | 6 Comments
  • NTAP

    NetApp's margin strength, buybacks boost EPS; shares +6.1% (updated)

    • Though NetApp's (NASDAQ:NTAP) revenue fell 10% Y/Y in FQ1, the company managed to post a gross margin of 63.6%, down just 70 bps Y/Y and up 160 bps Q/Q. Product GM fell 590 bps Y/Y to 51.2%, but services margins held up well.
    • Also lifting EPS: $430M was spent on buybacks, up from $246M in FQ4. Meanwhile, thanks to job cuts, operating expenses rose a modest 3% Y/Y to $746M.
    • Segment performance: Thanks to a mixture of share loss and weak enterprise storage demand, product sales (hardware/software, drives future maintenance revenue) fell 25% Y/Y to $664M. Software maintenance revenue rose 12% to $248M. Hardware maintenance/other services revenue rose 10% to $423M.
    • Other numbers: The Americas were 56% of revenue, EMEA 31%, and Asia-Pac 13%. 22% of revenue came from direct sales, and the rest from indirect sources (channel partners/OEMs). NetApp ended FQ1 with $5B in cash, and $1.5B in debt.
    • Shares have pared their after hours gains, but remain up sharply. Summit's pre-earnings downgrade isn't looking great.
    • FQ1 results, PR
    • Update (6:10PM ET): On its earnings call, NetApp guided for FY16 (ends April '16) revenue to fall ~5%. That's slightly better than a consensus for a 5.5% drop. Shares are now up 7% AH.
     
     
     
     
    | 4:54 PM
  • NTAP

    NetApp beats estimates, guides strong; shares soar (updated)

    • NetApp (NASDAQ:NTAP): FQ1 EPS of $0.29 beats by $0.06.
    • Revenue of $1.34B (-10.1% Y/Y) beats by $20M.
    • Expects FQ2 revenue of $1.4B-$1.5B and EPS of $0.55-$0.60, above a consensus of $1.39B and $0.46.
    • Shares +14.5% AH.
    • Update (5:10PM ET): NetApp has pared its gains: Shares are now up 5.2% AH. More details on the report here.
    • Update 2 (7:20PM ET): The roller coaster continues: Shares are now up 11.3% AH.
     
     
     
     
    | 4:05 PM | 3 Comments
  • INTU

    Deutsche upgrades Intuit ahead of earnings, expects strong subscriber growth

    • Deutsche's Nandan Amladi has upgraded Intuit (INTU +0.6%) to Buy ahead of tomorrow's FQ4 report, and hiked his target by $20 to $120.
    • Amladi: "While recent quarters have focused on the [QuickBooks Online] transition, we believe investor interest has now moved to how much upside INTU can generate over the next two years. We estimate INTU can overachieve the 2m subs target in Fiscal 2017 by over 10%, with up to $0.25 in EPS upside at the current growth momentum. A bit less competition from Xero recently and TAM expansion from INTU's early entry into the 'sharing economy' have boosted our confidence."
    • In May, Intuit forecast it would end FY15 (ended in July) with 1M-1.025M QuickBooks Online subs, up from prior guidance of 975K-1M. Shares are within $3 of a high of $109.21, hit the day after Intuit posted an FQ3 beat.
     
     
     
     
    | 2:49 PM
  • YNDX

    Yandex, Qiwi clocked as oil/ruble sell off

    • In a repeat of a story frequently seen in late 2014 and early 2015, Yandex (YNDX -3.9%) and Qiwi (QIWI -6.4%) are posting big losses as oil prices and the ruble fall sharply. WTI crude is down to $41.37/barrel following disappointing inventory data, and the ruble is now at 66.20 against the dollar.
    • Yandex, 3 weeks removed from delivering a Q2 miss, has made fresh 52-week lows, and is down 33% YTD. Qiwi, aided by well-received earnings and M&A, remains up 29% YTD. Q2 results are expected this month.
     
     
     
     
    | 2:30 PM

  • Stocks rebound from sharp declnes

    • The averages bottomed out more than 1% lower just before noon, and have been given an extra charge from the FOMC minutes which at first glance show maybe a smaller-than-expected sentiment for an imminent rate hike.
    • The Dow (DIA -0.1%), S&P 500 (SPY -0.1%), and Nasdaq 100 (QQQ +0.1%) have all returned to nearly flat.
    • The 10-year Treasury yield fell as low at 2.13% in the aftermath of the minutes from 2.23 earlier in the session. The rebound in stocks, however, is drawing some money out of fixed income, and the yield has bounced back to 2.15%. TLT +0.4%, TBT -0.8%
    • Oil continues sharply lower, and is within a few cents of trading with a $39 handle.
    • Gold (GLD +1.1%)  has added to gains post-minutes, now up 1.2% on the session at $1,130 per ounce.
    • Previously: FOMC minutes: Getting closer to rate hike (Aug. 19)
     
     
     
     
    | 2:16 PM | 34 Comments
  • SWKS

    Skyworks rebounds following CEO's Mad Money appearance

    • CEO David Aldrich used his appearance on yesterday evening's episode of Mad Money to downplay fears (heightened by Qorvo's calendar Q3 guidance) that Skyworks (SWKS +2.6%) will be hurt by weak Chinese demand: He noted only 20%-25% of the company's revenue comes from the Middle Kingdom, and that 4G growth is boosting Skyworks' average dollar content for local phone sales. "[W]e have high dollar content, few competitors, higher margins in a segment of the market that is growing quite strong,"
    • Aldrich also mentioned ~25% of Skyworks' revenue now comes from non-mobile sources. Design wins were landed in FQ3 (calendar Q2) for telematics systems, Zigbee smart lighting analog front-ends, set-top connectivity modules, and M2M systems.
    • Shares are recovering a chunk of the Tuesday losses seen amid a chip stock selloff. The Nasdaq is down slightly.
     
     
     
     
    | 2:13 PM | 11 Comments
  • SFTBY

    SoftBank up 4.4% on Arora's multimillion-dollar 'personal bet'

    • SoftBank (OTCPK:SFTBY) is up 4.4% in U.S. trading after overnight news that President Nikesh Arora is buying nearly half a billion dollars worth of the company's stock in the coming six months.
    • "I have decided to take a personal bet on the SoftBank Group and ensure an alignment of vision" with Chairman Masayoshi Son, he said.
    • Son expects Arora to be his successor -- and Arora is known not to be a big fan of the company's investment in Sprint, even while he pushes investments into Indian technology firms.
    • Arora has aid he has three criteria for making investments: market size, quality of the team, and the right business model.
    • Previously: SoftBank President takes massive stake in company (Aug. 19 2015)
    • Previously: Son facing down increasing doubts about Sprint's future (Aug. 12 2015)
     
     
     
     
    | 2:05 PM | 5 Comments
  • SPLS

    Citigroup points to positive signs with Staples

    • Underlying results from Staples (SPLS -1.4%) were strong in Q2, according to a read from Citigroup.
    • North American Commercial sales growth of 2.6% and a beat on the consolidated compstood out.
    • Citi thinks shares may be held back by ongoing concerns over the company's merger with Office Depot.
    • Previously: Staples EPS in-line, misses on revenue (Aug. 19 2015)
     
     
     
     
    | 1:33 PM | 1 Comment
  • CSIQ

    Solar stocks sell off as oil, energy stocks, Canadian Solar get hit

    • Solar stocks are underperforming (TAN -4%) as both oil and energy stocks post big losses following an unexpected rise in crude inventories, and Canadian Solar (CSIQ -20%) tumbles in the wake of a Q2 beat and light Q3 guidance. The Nasdaq is down 0.7%, and the S&P 0.8%.
    • Major decliners include David Einhorn/Stephen Mandel favorite SunEdison (SUNE -7.2%), which has nosedived since posting Q2 numbers on Aug. 6, and is a day removed from pricing a $650M convertible stock offering. Also selling off: Inverter/power optimizer maker SolarEdge (SEDG -9.6%), which tumbled last week in spite of an FQ4 beat and strong FQ1 guidance, and China's Trina (TSL -7.8%), which rose slightly yesterday following a Q2 beat and full-year guidance hike.
    • Other casualties include prominent U.S. names First Solar (FSLR -4.7%) and SolarCity (SCTY -3.7%), Chinese plays JinkoSolar (JKS -7.9%) and JA Solar (JASO -3.5%), and SunEdison YieldCos TerraForm Power (TERP -3.2%) and TerraForm Global (GLBL -3.6%).
    • Roth's Philip Shen is defending both Canadian and solar YieldCos. "Although yieldcos are no longer in vogue—for now —we fundamentally believe the quality of solar asset cash flows are high and that there is tremendous amount of growth ahead ... [Canadian's] management indicated that its yieldco launch remains on track for a YE'15 or early 2016 launch, and the confidential filing could occur soon ... Hypothetically, if CSIQ were not successful in launching its yieldco, the company would still be able to recycle its capital by selling its assets. Management believes this could drive $1bn of revenue in 2015, and we estimate this could represent ~$2.50 of EPS. "
    • Canaccord's Jonathan Dorsheimer: "We continue to believe that Canadian Solar's module business will experience a tightening supply/demand during this bullish end-of-year adoption cycle, which should benefit CSIQ's core operations. Although recent YieldCo and solar volatility have had dramatic valuation impacts, we believe the fundamental PV growth story is still intact."
     
     
     
     
    | 1:31 PM | 52 Comments
  • WIN

    Windstream expands fixed wireless offering to Philadelphia

    • Windstream Holdings (WIN -5.4%) says it's rolling out its fixed wireless connectivity solution in Philadelphia, opening a sixth market for its use of the technology.
    • The company currently offers business-targeted fixed wireless networking in Chicago, New York, northern New Jersey, Milwaukee, Wis., and Boston.
    • The solution, using microwave radio to transmit data from rooftop to rooftop, can be scaled for speeds up to 1 Gbps.
     
     
     
     
    | 1:21 PM | 3 Comments
  • PLUG

    Plug Power updates on Wal-Mart relationship

    • A new blog post from Plug Power (PLUG -2.4%) highlights progress of the company's relationship with Wal-Mart.
    • The company's hydrogen and fuel cell solutions are operational at 9 Wal-Mart distribution warehouse centers in six different U.S. states and two Canadian provinces.
    • During the firm's last earnings call, execs said the program will expand in 2016.
    • Plug Power earnings call transcript
     
     
     
     
    | 1:02 PM | 26 Comments
  • RYAM

    Amid panic, Rayonier Advanced seeks to clarify lawsuit

    • Rayonier Advanced Materials (NYSE:RYAM) provides more details on a lawsuit it filed against its largest customer - Eastman Chemical (EMN -2.8%) - last week. The stock just came off trading halt, and is now down 49% vs. 55% before the halt.
    • At issue is pricing on 7.5K metric tons per year - less than 2% of total expected cellulose specialties sale volume to all customers this year.
    • RYAM CEO Paul Boynton: "Pricing negotiations are always spirited debates around a number of factors and threatened or actual litigation is one tool that parties can employ ... We remain committed to resolving our differences with our largest customer in a constructive manner and continuing our 85 year relationship."
    • Previously: Rayonier Advanced Materials crumbles (Aug. 19)
     
     
     
     
    | 12:56 PM | 19 Comments

  • Midday Gainers / Losers

    • Gainers: CLTX +90%. HILL +87%. CRBP +55%. ACI +51%. CHLN +38%. SXE +26%. BLPH +20%. KIQ +19%. BTU +18%. CTRN +15%.
    • Losers: RYAM -55%. TEDU -21%. ECR -20%. FLXS -19%. CSIQ -19%. DL -17%. EROC -15%. BTE -15%. AAMC -15%. CERE -15%.
     
     
     
     
    | 12:45 PM | 9 Comments
  • GEVO

    Gevo up 9.7% on bullish H.C. Wainwright coverage

    • H.C. Wainwright has launched coverage on GEVO with a Buy rating and $5.00 target.
    • The launch comes two weeks after the biofuel maker posted a Q2 miss, and three weeks after it announced the start of pump sales for its isobutanol-blended gasoline.
     
     
     
     
    | 12:43 PM | 4 Comments
  • IGT

    IGT, Scientific Games sell off following bearish Goldman coverage

    • Goldman's Steven Kent has launched coverage on IGT (IGT -3.6%) with a Sell rating and $15.50 target, and on fellow gaming machine maker Scientific Games (SGMS -8.6%) with a Sell and $7.50 target.
    • Regarding IGT, Kent sees "limited clarity around [Gtech merger] synergies, cash use, and brand integration," and thinks the company will likely be “challenged by acquisition-related issues, declining market share, and concentration in Italy/lottery.” He adds a survey of slot managers indicated 44% plan to buy fewer IGT machines this year.
    • Likewise, Kent thinks SGMS could suffer "growing pains" related to the Bally Technologies merger, and notes it's "the single most levered company in our coverage [universe]," with $8.4B in net debt. Capex needs, meanwhile, are seen potentially offsetting operating expense cuts.
     
     
     
     
    | 12:32 PM | 3 Comments

  • Loonie takes out financial crisis lows as oil tumbles

    • The EIA earlier reported a surprise jump in crude inventories, and oil is down 4.2% to a new bear-market low of $40.86.
    • The resulting selloff in the loonie (FXC -0.7%) has that unit able to buy just $0.7595, the weakest since 2004.
    • The TSX 200 is down 1.05%, but EWC - priced in greenbacks - is off 1.8%.
     
     
     
     
    | 12:29 PM | 1 Comment
  • AMT

    MTN Group seeking up to $2B to sell mobile towers

    • South Africa's MTN Group (OTCPK:MTNOY -2.5%) is the latest to discuss a major cell-tower sale, having begun talks with tower operator IHS Holding over a possible $2B deal, Bloomberg reports.
    • MTN, with 231M subscribers across a 22-market footprint, has about 19,000 sites in South Africa.
    • The deal -- in which MTN could retain a large stake in the towers via a joint venture -- is the latest move in a bit of a wireless asset rush in Africa, with firms like Helios Towers Africa and American Tower (NYSE:AMT) looking to build infrastructure
    • IHS is Africa's largest independent tower company but may be racing to the deal against American Tower, which had previously expressed interest.
     
     
     
     
    | 11:45 AM
  • CSTE

    Caesarstone Sdit-Yam crumbles after short attack

    • Caesarstone Sdit-Yam (CSTE -11.6%) falls sharply after Spruce Point Management issues a new short report on the company,
    • The investment manager claims Caesarstone's margins are "significantly" overstated which leads to a massive overvaluation of share price by its reckoning.
     
     
     
     
    | 11:19 AM | 1 Comment
  • SXE

    Southcross Energy up 25% on new $175M equity commitment

    • Thinly traded Southcross Energy Partners (SXE +24.8%) heads north on a 5x surge in volume, albeit on turnover of only 623K, in response to its announcement that it secured a new equity commitment of $175M from three institutional investors.
    • Almost a third of the total, $50M, will fund growth opportunities in Eagle Ford, including organic capital projects and strategic acquisitions. It is also available for potential covenant cures and asset drop-downs. The capital will be structured to minimize potential dilution to current common unit holders.
    • The remaining $125M will be used to enhance the inventory of drop-down assets available to Southcross and potentially for direct investment in the company for future growth projects.
    • Southcross expects to achieve at least a 1.0x coverage ratio on current common units in Q4 and through next calendar year, assuming a quarterly distribution of $0.40 per common unit. It intends to complete a drop-down every four to six months, subject to conditions.
     
     
     
     
    | 11:18 AM
  • CVX

    Energy leads averages lower

    • It's a broad decline for stocks this morning, with the S&P 500, DJIA, and Nasdaq all lower by 1% or more. Leading the way down are the energy names (XLE -2.5%) after an unexpected jump in oil inventories has sent the price of black gold down to new bear market lows at $41.30 per barrel.
    • Chevron (CVX -2.9%), ConocoPhillips (COP -3.8%), EOG Resources (EOG -4.3%), Apache (APA -4.1%), Hess (HES -3.6%), Marathon Oil (MRO -5.5%), Noble Energy (NBL -3.1%), Anadarko (APC -3.6%).
    • ETFs: XLE, VDE, ERX, OIH, XOP, ERY, DIG, DUG, BGR, IYE, IEO, FENY, PXE, FIF, PXJ, NDP, RYE, FXN, DDG, DRIP, GUSH
     
     
     
     
    | 11:18 AM | 87 Comments
  • PLAB

    Photronics up 11.9% after FQ3 beat, strong EPS guidance

    • In addition to beating FQ3 estimates, Photronics (NASDAQ:PLAB) has guided in its earnings slides (.pdf) for FQ4 revenue of $129M-$138M and EPS of $0.15-$0.22 vs. a consensus of $133.4M and $0.12.
    • Margin gains are boosting EPS: Gross margin rose 230 bps Q/Q and 530 bps Y/Y in FQ3 to 28.3%, aided by improved manufacturing efficiencies. In addition, SG&A spend was nearly flat Y/Y at $12.4M. R&D spend rose 20% to $6.3M.
    • Display photomask sales were a strong point, rising 18% Q/Q to $27.7M with the help of strong OLED-related demand. High-end chip photomask sales (45nm manufacturing processes and lower) fell 6% Q/Q to $39M, while "mainstream" chip photomask sales rose 5% to $65M.
    • FQ3 results, PR
     
     
     
     
    | 11:02 AM
  • CTRN

    Citi Trends flies after strong earnings and dividend introduction

    • Citi Trends (NASDAQ:CTRN) is up 11% after earnings impress amid a tough day for broad retail (S&P Retail ETF -1.1%).
    • Cash flow is now strong enough at the company for it to initiate a cash dividend and launch a buyback plan.
    • Earlier this week, TJX Companies reported strong results for Q2.
    • Previously: Citi Trends declares $0.06 dividend
    • Previously: Citi Trends reports 3.9% comp for Q2
     
     
     
     
    | 10:55 AM
  • MEOH

    Methanex down 5.8% on Raymond James downgrade

    • Believing near-term energy blending demand will be soft and that methanol prices will see a muted recovery in 2016, Raymond James has downgraded Methanex (NASDAQ:MEOH) to Outperform from Strong Buy.
    • Shares have made new 52-week lows. They're down 33% from a May peak of $61.40.
     
     
     
     
    | 10:35 AM
  • ARCH

    With bankruptcy looming, Arch Coal up 46.6% on possible debt-swap compromise

    • Facing a bankruptcy filing after the expiration of its distressed debt exchange offer, Arch Coal (NYSE:ACI) is up 46.6% after a Bloomberg report saying that the company may compromise with lenders over a debt swap that could help it dodge a filing.
    • The company's loan holders might get a higher yield if they drop opposition to swapping up to $2.38B of junior debt for senior debt -- a deal proposed on July 2 and now extended to Aug. 28.
    • The swap plan's opponents have argued new creditors would receive preferential treatment over existing investors. Those opponents say they're in the majority of senior creditors.
    • The company's $1B in 7.25% senior unsecured bonds maturing June 2021 last traded at 8.63 cents/dollar on Monday.
    • Previously: Fitch: Worst not over for mining as Arch Coal bankruptcy filing looms (Aug. 13 2015)
    • Previously: Arch Coal is down but not out, Cowen analysts say (Aug. 03 2015)
     
     
     
     
    | 10:35 AM | 8 Comments
  • ATGE

    DeVry Education rallies after earnings

    • DeVry Education (DV +9.1%) trades higher despite missing earnings yesterday.
    • The company's International and Professional business was the only segment to show positive sales growth during the quarter.
    • Shares of DeVry didn't get any help from Compass Point which lowered its price target to $28 from $34, but are holding up amid speculation some shorts are getting squeezed.
    • Previously: DeVry Education misses by $0.04, misses on revenue (Aug. 18 2015)
     
     
     
     
    | 10:25 AM | 1 Comment
  • RYAM

    Rayonier Advanced Materials crumbles

    • Maybe the exception that proves Joel Greenblatt's rule that spinoffs offer outstanding investment possibilities, Rayonier Advanced Materials (RYAM -41.2%) last night disclosed its filing of a lawsuit attempting to enforce a contact with a customer, Eastman Chemical Company.
    • The stock has lost about 80% of its value since being spun off from Rayonier a bit more than a year ago.
     
     
     
     
    | 10:19 AM | 17 Comments
  • MNI

    McClatchy up 10.2% as it authorizes $15M buyback

    • McClatchy (NYSEMKT:MNI) is up 10.2% as it announces a new $15M stock repurchase program while receiving a noncompliance notice from the NYSE on its share price.
    • The board has authorized the company to buy back that amount in class A common stock through the end of 2016; the program replaces a limited $7M program for that time frame.
    • "As we have reviewed our strategies for investing in digital ventures, our stock price presents us with an attractive opportunity to invest in our growth markets and digital operations through a stock buyback program," says CEO Pat Talamantes.
    • The company received a notice from the NYSE that its common stock isn't in listing compliance, having dropped below $1/share. It has a six-month period to pursue lifting the stock price.
     
     
     
     
    | 10:13 AM | 1 Comment
  • HABT

    Habit Restaurants higher after Raymond James boost

    • Habit Restaurants (NASDAQ:HABT) is upgraded by Raymond James to an Outperform rating from Market Perform.
    • Raymond James was not one of the lead underwriters for the IPO, but is listed as an underwriter.
    • Shares of the restaurant chain are up 3.6% to $26.99 vs. a post-IPO trading range of $23.27 to $44.20.
     
     
     
     
    | 10:04 AM | 6 Comments
  • RMAX

    More losses for Re/Max on 2nd downgrade in 2 days

    • Today it's Morgan Stanley heading the sidelines on Re/Max (RMAX -5.2%), with a downgrade to Equalweight from Overweight. The price target is $40.
    • Previously: Compass Point rings the register on Re/Max (Aug. 18)
     
     
     
     
    | 9:54 AM | 1 Comment
  • AFL

    Aflac stung by BofA downgrade

    • Not expecting earning to improve over the next two years, analyst Seth Weiss downgrades Aflac (AFL -2.6%) to Underperform from Neutral, and cuts the price target to $66 from $68.
     
     
     
     
    | 9:50 AM | 14 Comments
  • AGI

    Alamos Gold up 12% on CIBC upgrade

  • CNET

    ChinaNet Online up 20% on Baidu partnership

    • ChinaNet Online (NASDAQ:CNET) is up 20.2% premarket after saying it's partnering with Baidu on a sales lead generation service to connect businesses with Chinese entrepreneurs.
    • The service, "The GOOD Business of China," takes advantage of Baidu's Tieba forum posting platform to provide "online-to-offline" services -- online marketing and data exchange, and search and roadshow features.
    • The launch just over a week ago has brought 45 businesses that have pledged up to RMB100M funding support to qualified entrepreneurs. More than 100 businesses are waiting to be added, the company says.
    • Previously: ChinaNet Online reports Q2 results (Aug. 17 2015)

  • CRBP

    Corbus Pharma's Resunab Fast Track'd; shares up 47% premarket

    • Thinly traded nano cap Corbus Pharmaceuticals (NASDAQ:CRBP) jumps 47% premarket on robust volume in response to its announcement that its lead product candidate, Resunab, has been tagged for Fast Track review by the FDA for the treatment of systemic sclerosis (scleroderma), a serious life-threatening autoimmune disorder characterized by chronic activation of the immune system. There are no FDA-approved treatments for the condition.
    • Resunab is a novel synthetic oral endocannabinoid-mimic that binds to the CB2 receptor on immune cells and fibroblasts. Binding to CB2 triggers the production of "Specialized Pro-resolving Lipid Mediators" which activates a process that restores the chronically activated immune system back to homeostasis and stops fibrosis without suppressing the immune system.
    • Fast Track status provides for a rolling review of the New Drug Application (NDA) and shortens the review clock to six months.
     
     
     
     
    | 8:31 AM | 1 Comment
  • TGT

    Target boosts full-year profit view

    • Target (NYSE:TGT) reports comparable-store sales increased 2.4% in Q2 on transaction growth.
    • The retailer's U.S. comp was higher than Wal-Mart's for the second consecutive quarter.
    • Selling price per unit +3.8% Y/Y.
    • Growth in the Style, Baby, and Kids and Wellness categories were 3X the company average.
    • Gross margin rate +50 bps to 30.9%.
    • EBITDA margin rate +100 bps to 10.9%.
    • Digital sales rose over 30% during the quarter to contribute 60 bps of comp growth.
    • Consolidated SG&A expenses rate -60 bps to 19.9% as cost savings factored in.
    • RedCard penetration +30 bps to 22.1%.
    • Total store count +4 Y/Y to 1,799.
    • Guidance: Q3 EPS of $0.79-$0.89 expected vs. $0.86 consensus. 2015 EPS of $4.60-$4.75 seen vs. $4.50-$4.56 prior and $4.62 consensus.
    • Previously: Target beats by $0.11, beats on revenue
    • TGT +4.35% premarket to $83.79.
